questions.text: The spina ventosa is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Spina ventosa/Tuberculous dactylitis is a rare skeletal tuberculosis of short tubular bones like phalanges, metacarpals, and metatarsals.
  • This condition is uncommon after the age of 5 years. It is also known as tuberculosis dactylitis.
  • In this condition, the hand is more frequently involved than the foot.
  • Due to abundant blood flow through the large nutrient artery, almost in the middle of the bone, the first inoculum of infection, lodged in the centre of the marrow cavity, leads to the spindle-shaped expansion of bone called spina ventosa.
  • The term "spina ventosa" literally means "wind-filled sail" due to the appearance of the bone on X-ray.

Explanation of other options:

Carpals (Option A): Less commonly involved due to poor vascular supply in comparison to phalanges.

Ventral spine (Option C): Not the site of spina ventosa; vertebral involvement in TB is known as Pott's disease.

Shoulder joint (Option D): TB of the shoulder is termed Caries sicca, not spina ventosa.

Key Takeaway:

Spina ventosa (tuberculous dactylitis) typically affects short tubular bones like the phalanges in children under 5 years.

questions.text: Caries sicca is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Caries sicca is a dry form of tuberculous arthritis that characteristically involves the shoulder joint, presenting with marked stiffness and minimal swelling or abscess.

  • Tuberculosis of the shoulder often presents in the dry (caries sicca) form, as opposed to the moist (abscess-forming) variety.
  • Patients have pain, stiffness, and progressive functional loss but usually lack joint swelling or pus.
  • On imaging, findings include osteopenia, marginal erosions, and joint space narrowing without aggressive destruction.
  • It can mimic a frozen shoulder and should be considered in chronic monoarthritis of the shoulder.

Explanation of other options:

Hip (Option A): TB of the hip is common but typically presents with synovial effusion and joint destruction, not caries sicca.

Spine (Option B): TB of the spine (Pott's disease) involves vertebral bodies and is not referred to as caries sicca.

Knee (Option D): TB of the knee commonly presents with boggy swelling and cold abscess formation, not the dry form.

Key Takeaway:

Caries sicca is the classic dry tuberculous arthritis of the shoulder joint, characterised by stiffness with minimal or no swelling.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with chronic back pain, low-grade fever, and constitutional symptoms. MRI of the thoracolumbar spine reveals vertebral body destruction and paravertebral abscess formation. In spinal tuberculosis (Pot's disease), which of the following vertebral structures is least likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In spinal tuberculosis, the anterior part of the vertebral body is most commonly affected, while the posterior elements, like the spinous processes, are least involved.

  • TB of the spine primarily begins in the anterior part of the vertebral body near the endplate.
  • It spreads beneath the longitudinal ligament and to adjacent vertebrae, often leading to collapse and kyphotic deformity.
  • Posterior elements such as pedicles, laminae, and spinous processes are rarely involved.
  • Involvement of the spinous process, facet joint, or lamina is more characteristic of atypical or advanced disease.

Explanation of other options:

Body (Option A): The most commonly affected site in typical spinal TB is due to its rich vascular supply.

Lamina (Option B): Can be involved in extensive disease, but is not typically affected early.

Pedicle (Option D): Occasionally involved but still more commonly affected than the spinous process.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with chronic mid-back pain, weight loss, and low-grade fever. MRI of the spine shows destruction of the adjacent endplates of T10 and T11 vertebral bodies along with collapse of the intervening disc. Which of the following is the most common pattern of vertebral involvement seen in Pott's spine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

There are 4 patterns of vertebral involvement in Pott's spine:

  1. Paradiscal(due to arterial spread) - This is the commonest. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae, along with the intervening disc, are affected.
    • Paradiscal TB results from arterial hematogenous spread to the subchondral region of two adjacent vertebral bodies.
    • The intervening disc gets involved secondarily, leading to collapse and kyphotic deformity.
    • This form accounts for more than 90% of spinal TB cases.
  2. Central(due to venous spread) - In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to the early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal. (Option A ruled out)
  3. Anterior(due to subperiosteal spread) - In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament. (Option B ruled out)
  4. Appendiceal and posterior type- Occurs in isolation involving pedicles, laminae, transverse process and spinous process or in conjunction with the typical paradisical variant. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 42-year-old manual labourer presents with chronic back pain, low-grade fever, and weight loss. On examination, there is a localised paraspinal spasm and an extensor plantar response. MRI is planned to evaluate possible spinal tuberculosis. Which of the following spinal regions is most commonly involved in such cases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The thoracolumbar region (lower thoracic and upper lumbar vertebrae) is the most commonly involved site in spinal tuberculosis, due to mechanical and anatomical vulnerability.

  • The dorsolumbar junction is a transitional zone between the rigid thoracic spine and the mobile lumbar spine, making it mechanically prone to stress.
  • This region bears a significant load of axial weight and has a rich vascular supply via the venous plexus, making it a favourable site for hematogenous spread.
  • The vertebral bodies here have a large volume of cancellous bone, ideal for harbouring Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • TB spreads hematogenously via Batson's venous plexus or lymphatics from mesenteric nodes.

The majority of cases are reported in the dorsolumbar region(lower thoracic and upper lumbar) due to:

  • Greater extent of movement - stress zone due to transition of kyphosis to lordosis
  • Degree of weight-bearing
  • Large surface area of spongy cancellous bone
  • Proximity to the cisterna chyli and the kidney.

In order of involvement:

Dorso lumbar → upper dorsal → Cervical → sacral → atlantoaxial

Explanation of other options:

Sacral (Option B): Least commonly affected; relatively immobile and has a smaller cancellous volume.

Cervical (Option C): Less commonly involved; but when affected, present earlier with neurologic signs due to canal narrowing.

Lumbosacral (Option D): Involvement is less common than thoracolumbar; isolated lumbosacral TB is rare.

questions.text:
Which of the following are indicators of poor prognosis in a patient with spinal tuberculosis (Pott's spine)?
1. Healed vertebral disc
2. Grade IV neurological deficit
3. Kyphotic angle >60°
4. Incomplete cord involvement
5. Younger age with good nutrition
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Healed lesions, severe neurological deficits, and kyphotic deformity are known indicators of poor prognosis in spinal TB.

  • Healed vertebral lesion: Indicates inactive disease; neurological symptoms may persist due to mechanical compression.
  • Grade IV neurological deficit: Complete motor and sensory loss suggests severe and chronic cord damage.
  • Kyphotic angle >60°: Associated with significant deformity and risk of late-onset paraplegia or mechanical instability.

Factors leading to:

  • Poor prognosis in Potts spine:
    • Inactive disease with poor mechanical compression
    • Complete paralysis/Complete cord involvement
    • Paralysis for more than 1 year
    • Presence of severe kyphosis(>60 degree)
    • Older age and poor nutrition
    • Healed vertebral lesion
    • Presence of myelomalacia and syringomyelia on magnetic resonance imaging(MRI).
  • A good prognosis is associated with:
    • Inflammatory cause of cord involvement
    • Incomplete involvement
    • Short duration of deficit
    • Minimal kyphotic deformity
    • Younger age
    • Good nutritional status.

Explanation of other options:

Other options are ruled out in the explanation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with a history of spinal tuberculosis. He has completed antitubercular therapy. On follow-up radiographs, there is evidence of vertebral body fusion and loss of disc space. What are the most common sequelae of tuberculous spondylitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bony ankylosis is the most common sequelae of tuberculous spondylitis due to progressive caseation, vertebral collapse, and healing by bone fusion.

  • Tuberculous spondylitis is most commonly localised in the thoracic portion of the spine.
  • The infection comes from the primary site(ie, lungs) and then spreads from two adjacent vertebrae into the adjoining intervertebral disc space. If only one vertebra is affected, the disc is normal, but if two are involved, the avascular disc cannot receive nutrients and collapses. The disc tissue dies and is broken down by caseation, leading to vertebral narrowing and eventually to vertebral collapse(Bony ankylosis) and spinal damage. Over time, healing occurs by fusion of vertebrae (bony ankylosis), resulting in stiffness and deformity (kyphosis).

Explanation of other options:

Fibrous ankylosis (Option A): Seen in peripheral tuberculous arthritis, not in the spine.

Pathological dislocation (Option C): Rare in TB spine; may occur in atlantoaxial TB, but not common.

Chronic osteomyelitis (Option D): More typical of pyogenic infections, not TB.

questions.text: Most common site for osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The metaphysis is the most frequent site of acute hematogenous osteomyelitis due to its looping end-arterial vascular pattern and high metabolic activity.

  • Blood vessels in the metaphyseal zone are arranged in the form of a loop(hairpin arrangement). The blood stasis resulting from such an arrangement is probably responsible for the metaphysis being a favourite site for bacteria to settle and thus a common site for osteomyelitis.
  • The growth plate acts as a barrier, preventing spread to the epiphysis in growing individuals.
  • Hematogenous osteomyelitis is an infection caused by bacterial seeding from the blood.
  • Acute hematogenous osteomyelitis is characterised by an acute infection of the bone caused by the seeding of bacteria within the bone from a remote source. This condition primarily occurs in children.
  • The most common site is the rapidly growing and highly vascular metaphysis of growing bones. The apparent slowing or sludging of blood flow as the vessels make sharp angles at the distal metaphysis predisposes the vessels to thrombosis and the bone itself to localised necrosis and bacterial seeding
  • MC site of OM in child: Lower end of the femur
  • MC site of OM in adults: Thoraco-Lumbar vertebra(Thoracic > Lumbar)
  • MC site of OM in infants: Hip

Explanation of other options:

Epiphysis (Option A): Growth plate blocks spread; less commonly involved.

Diaphysis (Option C): Less vascular than metaphysis; seen in chronic or direct infections.

Subchondral growth plate (Option D): Not a primary site for hematogenous osteomyelitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding chronic osteomyelitis?
1. Reactive new bone formation occurs
2. Cloaca is an opening in the skin
3. Involucrum is a dead bone that contains the infection
4. Sequestrum is hard and porous
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic osteomyelitis involves a sequestrum (dead bone) surrounded by infected granulation tissue and a reactive shell of new bone (involucrum). Over time, pus and necrotic fragments are expelled through cloacae, which are channels within the involucrum, not the skin.

Pathology in chronic osteomyelitis

  • Chronic osteomyelitis occurs most commonly in long bones.
  • Bone is destroyed or devitalized in the affected part. Cavities containing pus and pieces of dead bone(sequestra) are surrounded by vascular tissue and beyond that by areas of sclerosis due to the reaction of new bone formation, which may take the form of a distinct bony sheath(involucrum).
  • Often, sinus tracts lead to the skin surface; the sinus tends to heal and present down recurrently, but if a sequestrum is present, it never heals permanently.
  • This is because sequestra act as substrate for bacterial adhesion in much the same way as foreign implants, ensuring the persistence of infection until they are removed or discharged through perforations in the involucrum and sinuses that drain to the skin.

Sequestrum

  • Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue, trying to eat the sequestrum away.
  • The sequestrum is hard, rough, porous, light in weight and lighter in colour than normal. The normal pattern of bone is lost. (Note: Sequestrum in syphilis and TB is heavier than normal bone because sclerosis usually precedes the death of the bone)
  • On x-ray, sequestra show up as unnatural dense fragments, in contrast to the surrounding osteopenic bone.

Involucrum

  • Involucrum is a reactive new bone overlying a sequestrum.
  • There may be some holes in the involucrum for pus to drain out. These holes are called the Cloaca.

Explanation of other options:

Cloaca is an opening in the skin (Option 2): It is an opening in the involucrum to discharge pus/sequestrum.

Involucrum is dead bone (Option 3): It is the new bone formed around the sequestrum.

Key Takeaway:

Chronic osteomyelitis is marked by sequestrum (dead bone), involucrum (new bone), and cloacae (draining tracts in bone).

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with a draining sinus on his left leg with pus discharge and discharge of bony pieces for 3 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic osteomyelitis typically presents with a long-standing discharging sinus, intermittent pus, and discharge of sequestrum (dead bone). The general symptoms seen in acute cases, like fever or significant pain, are often absent.

Chronic osteomyelitis:

  • Clinical features of chronic osteomyelitis
    • The commonest presenting symptom is a chronic discharging sinus. Pain is minimal or absent
    • Generalised symptoms of acute osteomyelitis are not present except in acute exacerbations.
  • On examination,
    • There is irregular thickening of the bone
    • Mild tenderness may be seen in deep palpation
    • The adjacent joint may be stiff.

Radiological features: The Following are radiological features:

  • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices.
  • Patchy sclerosis
  • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis.
  • Sequestrum: This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification, which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissue.
  • Involucrum and cloacae may be visible.

Explanation of other options:

Acute osteomyelitis (Option A): More acute pain, systemic symptoms (fever), no chronic sinus or bony discharge.

Mycetoma (Option C): Chronic condition with discharging sinuses but involves granules, not bone; usually painless.

Cellulitis (Option D): Soft tissue infection; does not involve bony destruction or chronic sinus formation.

Key Takeaway:

A chronic discharging sinus with pus and dead bone fragments is diagnostic of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child comes with fever and tibial swelling, on X-ray exhibiting periosteal reaction. Laboratory results show raised ESR and TLC What is the next step in the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A 7-year-old child comes with fever and tibial swelling, on X-ray exhibiting periosteal reaction. Laboratory results show raised ESR and TLC. Differential diagnosis in this situation is either osteomyelitis or Ewing's sarcoma.

  • MRI is the next step in differentiating osteomyelitis or Ewing's sarcoma.
  • The best investigation is bone Biopsy.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging in:
    • Ewing's sarcoma: MRI is essential to elucidate soft-tissue involvement in Ewing's sarcoma, because the tumour has low signal intensity on T1-weighted images compared with the normal high signal intensity of the bone marrow.
    • Osteomyelitis: MRI allows early detection of osteomyelitis and assessment of the extent of involvement and the activity of the disease in cases of chronic bone infection. It is considered the most useful imaging technique to evaluate suspected osteomyelitis because of its ability to demonstrate changes in the water content of bone marrow with an excellent structural definition and spatial resolution. MRI is highly sensitive for detecting osteomyelitis as early as 3 to 5 days after the onset of infection.
  • Bone biopsy differentiates Ewing's sarcoma from osteomyelitis. On histopathology, round neural cells containing glycogen and Reticulin are seen. The cytoplasm is PAS positive and diastase digestible.
  • A 5-year-old boy presents with pain and swelling in the diaphysis of the tibia. He also complains of fever. On examination, his ESR was raised. Ewing sarcoma is the most likely diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Bone biopsy (Option A): Best for tissue diagnosis, but not the immediate next step in a febrile child.

Blood culture (Option B): Important for guiding antibiotic therapy, but has low yield and comes after imaging.

Pus culture (Option D): Requires local collection, which may not be feasible without a drainable focus.

Key Takeaway:

In pediatric bone pain with systemic signs and an ambiguous X-ray, MRI is the next diagnostic step to differentiate between osteomyelitis and malignancy like Ewing's sarcoma.

questions.text: What is the most common location of Brodie's abscess?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brodie's abscess is a localised form of subacute or chronic osteomyelitis, usually seen in children and adolescents with unfused epiphyseal plates.

  • It typically affects the metaphyseal region of long bones.
  • Tibia, particularly the proximal or distal metaphysis, is the most common site.
  • Presents with mild pain and tenderness, often without systemic features.
  • Imaging may show a well-circumscribed lucency with sclerotic margins.

Explanation of other options:

Distal end of ulna (Option A): Rarely involved in Brodie abscess.

Femoral metaphysis (Option B): Commonly involved, but less frequently than the tibia.

Distal end radius (Option D): Not a classical site for Brodie abscess.

Key Takeaway:

The tibial metaphysis is the most common site of Brodie abscess, a localised intraosseous abscess seen in subacute osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a deep, boring pain over the upper end of the tibia that worsens at night and is relieved by rest. There is no fever. X-ray shows a small, well-defined lytic lesion with a surrounding sclerotic margin in the metaphyseal region of the tibia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brodie's abscess is a localised form of subacute osteomyelitis that typically occurs in immunocompetent adolescents, commonly between 11-20 years of age.

  • Most frequently affects the metaphysis of long bones, especially the upper tibia and lower femur.
  • Pain is often dull, boring, worsens at night, and improves with rest.
  • X-ray shows a small, lytic cavity with a sclerotic rim and minimal periosteal reaction.
  • Caused by low-virulence organisms, most commonly Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Treatment involves surgical curettage and antibiotics.

Explanation of other options:

Osteomyelitis (Option A): Typically more acute; associated with fever, systemic signs, and aggressive periosteal reaction.

Osteoid osteoma (Option B): Also presents with night pain but typically involves the diaphysis and nidus with central calcification.

Giant cell tumour (Option C): Usually occurs after physeal closure, in the epimetaphyseal region of long bones.

Key Takeaway:

Brodie's abscess is a classic cause of chronic metaphyseal pain with a sclerotic rim and is the subacute osteomyelitis form in healthy adolescents.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy, Tushar, presents to the emergency department with high-grade fever and deep, localised pain in his right lower leg for the past 3 days. He has a history of similar episodes over the past several years. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common causative organism of osteomyelitis, particularly in:

  • Acute hematogenous spread in children
  • Immunocompromised individuals, including HIV-positive patients
  • Post-traumatic osteomyelitis
  • Hematogenous seeding without an obvious external cause

Other organism-specific scenarios:

  • Salmonella is the most common organism in sickle cell anaemia.
  • Pseudomonas is typically seen in IV drug abusers and open wounds, especially of the foot.
  • Streptococcus may be a causative organism, but much less common than Staphylococcus aureus in all age groups.

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus (Option B): Less common cause; possible but not the leading pathogen in typical pediatric cases.

Pseudomonas (Option C): More common in open injury, IV drug use, or foot infections.

Salmonella (Option D): Classic in sickle cell anaemia, not in immunocompetent children.

Key Takeaway:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequent cause of acute osteomyelitis across multiple clinical settings.

questions.text: Earliest X-ray finding in osteomyelitis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The earliest visible change in osteomyelitis on X-ray is periosteal reaction, which typically appears around 7–10 days after the onset of infection.

  • Initial X-rays may appear normal in the first 24-48 hours.
  • Loss of soft tissue planes may be the first nonspecific sign after 24 hours.
  • Periosteal reaction is followed by lytic changes, sequestrum formation, and eventually involucrum and cloacae.

Types of periosteal reaction:

Explanation of other options:

Involucrum (Option A): New bone over dead bone appears later.

Sequestrum (Option B): Dead bone fragment, visible in late stages.

Cloacae (Option C): Opening in the involucrum allowing pus drainage, a late feature.

Key Takeaway:

Periosteal reaction is the earliest detectable X-ray sign in osteomyelitis, appearing around 7-10 days after onset.

questions.text: Felon means infection of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Felons/Whitlow are closed-space infections of the fingertip pulp. Infection occurring within these compartments can lead to abscess formation, oedema and rapid development of increased pressure in a closed space. This increased pressure may compromise blood flow and lead to necrosis of the skin and pulp.

  • Clinical feature: Felons are characterised by marked throbbing pain, tension and oedema of the fingertip pulp.
  • Causes: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause.
  • Management: The felon should be incised in the area of maximum tenderness. The incision should not cross the distal interphalangeal(DIP) joint to prevent the formation of a flexion contracture at the DIP flexion crease. Probing is not carried out proximally to avoid extension of infection into the flexor tendon sheath.
  • Complication of felon: Osteomyelitis > Tenosynovitis

Explanation of other options:

Epinychium (Option A): Refers to the cuticle; inflammation here is seen in paronychia, not felon.

Deep palmar abscess (Option C): Occurs in the deep palmar space, not the terminal pulp.

Subcuticular space abscess (Option D): Not the same as a pulp-space infection; refers to superficial skin abscesses, not compartmental fingertip involvement.

Key Takeaway:

Felon is a surgical emergency involving infection of the terminal pulp space, requiring early incision to prevent necrosis and bone involvement.

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.text: Wandering acetabulum is typically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wandering acetabulum is a late-stage radiological and clinical finding in tuberculous arthritis of the hip, where destruction of the acetabulum and femoral head leads to dislocation and migration of the femoral head superiorly and posteriorly. A false acetabulum may form, described as the wandering acetabulum.

  • The disease progresses through four stages: synovitis → early arthritis → late arthritis → arthritis with subluxation/dislocation.
  • Progressive destruction of the femoral head and acetabulum leads to pathological dislocation, muscle contractures, and false acetabulum formation.
  • This gives rise to a classical radiologic picture described as "wandering acetabulum."

The TB HIP progresses through the following clinical stages:

1. Stage 1 - Synovitis:

  • Joint held in flexion, abduction, and external rotation due to effusion. X-ray shows widened joint space and generalised osteopenia.

2. Stage 2 - Early Arthritis:

  • Articular cartilage destruction with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformity. Apparent shortening present; X-ray shows decreased joint space.

3. Stage 3 - Late Arthritis:

  • Severe deformities, true shortening >1 cm, marked movement restriction, and muscle wasting. X-ray reveals loss of joint space and destruction of the head/acetabulum.

4. Stage 4 - Subluxation/Dislocation:

  • Gross shortening with femoral head displaced dorsally, forming a false acetabulum (wandering acetabulum). "Mortar and pestle" appearance may be seen. Leads to pathological dislocation.

Explanation of other options:

Avascular necrosis of the femoral head (Option A): Causes collapse and sclerosis of the femoral head, not dislocation or acetabular migration.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip (Option B): Involves a shallow acetabulum and dislocated femoral head, but does not form a false acetabulum in the same way as TB.

Dislocation of femur (Option C): May be traumatic, but does not produce wandering acetabulum, which is specific to chronic TB.

Key Takeaway:

Wandering acetabulum is a late consequence of TB hip due to joint destruction, dislocation, and formation of a false acetabulum.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a gradual-onset pain and swelling in the left knee for 6 months. Over the past month, he has developed a limp and a mild flexion deformity. Ultrasound shows synovial thickening. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tuberculous arthritis typically presents as a monoarticular joint involvement, with a chronic onset of swelling and pain, commonly affecting large joints like the knee.

  • Initial symptoms include vague joint pain, swelling, and stiffness, especially in young adults.
  • The joint is typically held in a position of ease, with mild flexion in the knee.
  • Muscle wasting is often disproportionately more than disuse would cause.
  • As the disease progresses, cold abscesses, sinus formation, and progressive deformity (triple deformity: flexion, posterior subluxation, external rotation) may develop.
  • USG or MRI may show synovial hypertrophy, joint effusion, or cartilage loss.
  • Differential diagnoses like PVNS, synovial sarcoma, and chronic osteomyelitis lack this combination of insidious onset, monoarticular involvement, and deformity.

Explanation of other options:

Pigmented villonodular synovitis (Option B): Presents with chronic swelling but lacks constitutional symptoms or cold abscess formation.

Synovial sarcoma (Option C): Typically, a painful, enlarging soft-tissue mass, not limited to the joint cavity.

Chronic osteomyelitis (Option D): Primarily a bone infection with sinus and sequestrum; joint involvement is secondary.

Key Takeaway:

Chronic monoarticular joint pain with swelling, deformity, and synovial thickening should raise suspicion of tuberculous arthritis.

choices.text: Valgus trauma to the knee joint

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with chronic pain, swelling, and stiffness in the left knee. Examination reveals flexion deformity, lateral rotation of the tibia, and posterior subluxation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Triple deformity of the knee-defined as flexion, lateral (external) rotation, and posterior subluxation of the tibia-is classically seen in advanced tuberculosis of the knee joint.

  • The deformity results from ligamentous laxity and progressive joint destruction due to chronic tuberculous synovitis.
  • Initially, there is flexion deformity from effusion and spasm. Over time, this progresses to subluxation and rotational deformities.
  • Though also described in RA, TB is the classical and most characteristic cause.
  • Management involves anti-tubercular therapy and, in advanced cases, surgical intervention such as arthrodesis.

Explanation of other options:

Fracture patella (Option A): Presents with pain and inability to extend the knee; deformity is not triple-type.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option C): Can mimic deformities but usually involves multiple joints; TB remains the classical cause.

Valgus trauma to the knee joint (Option D): May produce ligamentous injury (e.g., O'Donoghue's triad) but does not cause the classical triple deformity.

Key Takeaway:

Triple deformity of the knee (flexion, lateral rotation, posterior subluxation) is characteristically seen in tuberculous arthritis of the knee.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the dental clinic by his parents with a complaint of painless swelling along the lower jaw. The swelling has been gradually increasing for several weeks. There is no history of fever, trauma, or recent dental procedures. On examination, a firm, bony-hard swelling is noted along the inferior border of the mandible. Radiographs reveal a layered periosteal reaction resembling an "onion-skin" pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Garré's osteomyelitis is a non-suppurative, chronic form of sclerosing osteomyelitis, often seen in children and adolescents, especially in the mandible.

  • It usually follows a low-grade chronic infection, commonly dental in origin.
  • Radiographically shows "onion-skin" type periosteal new bone formation.
  • Presents as a firm, bony swelling without systemic signs or pus discharge.
  • No sinus formation is seen, and swelling is often painless or mildly tender.
  • Treatment includes rest, antibiotics, and, occasionally, surgical decompression if painful.

Explanation of other options:

Ewing's sarcoma (Option A): Also shows onion-skin appearance but is typically painful, with systemic symptoms like fever, and diaphyseal location in long bones.

Chronic suppurative osteomyelitis (Option B): Presents with sinus formation and pus discharge, not typical of Garré's variant.

Fibrous dysplasia (Option D): Presents with ground-glass appearance on imaging, not onion-skin periosteal reaction.

Key Takeaway:

Garré's osteomyelitis is a non-suppurative form of chronic osteomyelitis with bony swelling and onion-skin periosteal reaction, classically affecting the mandible in young patients.

questions.text: Earliest change of osteomyelitis on X-Ray
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Loss of soft tissue planes is the earliest radiological change seen in osteomyelitis, appearing within the first 24- 48 hours of infection.

  • Plain X-rays are typically normal during the first 24 hours.
  • Soft tissue swelling leads to obliteration of normal fat planes, which becomes detectable earliest.
  • Periosteal reaction appears after 7-10 days, typically when pus elevates the periosteum.
  • Lytic areas and sequestra take 2-3 weeks to appear radiographically, due to bone resorption and necrosis.

Explanation of other options:

  • Lytic defects (Option A): Develop later, usually after 10-14 days, due to bone destruction.
  • Sequestrum (Option C): Seen in chronic osteomyelitis; appears as dense dead bone, usually after several weeks.
  • Periosteal reaction (Option D): Typically, the second radiological sign, appearing after 7-10 days.

Key Takeaway:

Loss of soft tissue planes due to swelling is the earliest detectable change on X-ray in osteomyelitis, before bone changes become visible.
